title: How to make perfect pork crackling: Italian chef reveals why a HAIR DRYER is the secret
text:
An Italian chef has revealed the secret to the 'perfect' pork crackling.

Stefano de Pieri, the owner of Stefano's in Mildura, Victoria, said the trick is ensuring the skin of the pork is totally dry before seasoning with olive oil and fine salt.

Mr de Pieri said some chefs dry the skin with a hairdryer, while others leave it unwrapped in the fridge for 12 hours to remove excess moisture.

Italian chef Stefano di Pieri says the trick to perfect pork crackling is ensuring the skin is bone dry before seasoning

Mr de Pieri (pictured) said pork skin should be dried with a hair dryer or left unwrapped in a fridge for 12 hours to remove excess moisture

What is porchetta? Porchetta is a savoury, fatty and moist boneless pork roast from Italian culinary tradition. The carcass is deboned, stuffed with herbs like fennel and sage and roasted over wood for eight hours.

One of the finest cuts of roast pork is porchetta, an Italian dish stuffed with herbs and roasted over wood for eight hours.

Sharing his recipe for perfect porchetta with Good Food Australia, Mr de Pieri starts by preheating the oven to 240C.

While waiting for the temperature to rise, he scores the skin and fat with a sharp Stanley knife without cutting into the flesh.

While conventional roast pork recipes advise patting the skin dry with paper towels, Mr de Pieri goes one step further by unwrapping the meat and leaving it in the fridge for 12 hours to remove all moisture.

What cuts of pork are good for roasting? - Shoulder - Scotch roast - Loin - Topside - Mini roast Source: Pork.com.au

What cuts of pork are good for roasting? - Loin chops - Rack - Rolled belly - Rolled loin - Leg Source: Pork.com.au





Before cooking, he rubs the skin with olive oil and fine grain salt.

Mr de Pieri places the meat in a roasting dish and leaves the dial at 240C to allow crackling to form.

Crackling takes between 30 and 45 minutes, and appears when moisture boils into steam which expands forcing the skin to crack and bubble.

Once the skin has blistered, reduce heat to 170C.

Pork takes roughly 30 minutes to cook per 450g, plus another 30 minutes on lower heat according to Good Food Australia.

Pork crackling takes between 30 and 45 minutes to form at 240C heat

In countries where trichinosis is a problem, undercooked pork should be avoided.

Trichinosis, a form of roundworm infection triggered by a parasitic larvae that lives in the muscles of pigs, causes abdominal cramps, vomiting and diarrhoea.

The condition is found across North America, Japan, China and tropical Africa.

Australia is not affected by trichinosis so quality sourced pork can be enjoyed pink, Good Food Australia reports.
description: Italian chef Stefano de Pieri, of Stefano's in Mildura, Victoria, says the secret to perfecting pork crackling is ensuring the skin of the meat is totally dry before seasoning.
authors: Alice Murphy For Daily Mail Australia
